author: .vbuterin
content: > <@!375471494081282048> I think the fee burning may be treated as taxes and the economical models usually say that introduction of taxes is being split between miners and users in a ratio dependent on the price elasticity. <@!273808422753796097> was calculating the elasticity to be around 2 recently so I think we can exactly calculate the percentage of the tax that will be absorbed by the miners (should be 60% or so of the top of my head?)

author: .vbuterin
content: Because it's not a new tax being introduced, it's an existing regulatory mechanism (the quantity limit) being replaced by a new regulatory mechanism (the floating fee)

author: .vbuterin
content: so the outcome should be that average fees stay about the same but instead of the fee going to miners a large part of it gets burned

author: .vbuterin
content: at more-than-very-short timescales, the supply curve is still a vertical line at 10 million, so the gasprice that users pay will still be the intersection of that vertical line with their demand curve

author: abdel.stark
content: <@!273808422753796097> Is the x2 block elasticity required to preserve the benefits of EIP-1559 Would it work with something less, x1.5 for example ? We talked with Geth team and they are really concerned about the x2 multiplier, saying that the system already operates at its limit.

author: abdel.stark
content:
> x1.5 would allow 33% attacks
<@!273808422753796097> Could you explain briefly how ?

author: sky.cactus
content: The lower the elasticity, the less hash power is required to drive the base fee down.

author: .vbuterin
content: Basically you only need 34% to mine empty blocks to make the average block size below the target

author: sky.cactus
content: It doesn't break things entirely, it is still non-profitable to mine empty blocks.

author: sky.cactus
content: However, the larger the elasticity, the harder it is (more hashing power required to collude) to force the base fee down by mining empty blocks.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you go down to 1x elasticity, it takes 0 hash power to mine enough empty blocks to drive the base fee to 0.  ðŸ˜‰
